unnormalised: ## Don't Get Naive: Decoding Your Rental Agreement, Bhai!
normalised: Do not get naive: decoding your rental agreement, bhai!

unnormalised: So, you've finally found that perfect flat near IIT Bombay! Congratulations, Sharma ji! Now comes the not-so-fun part: the rental agreement. I know, I know, it looks like a bunch of legal mumbo-jumbo, but trust me, spending a little time understanding it can save you a whole lot of headache later.
normalised: So, you have finally found that perfect flat near I I T Bombay! Congratulations, Sharma ji! Now comes the not so fun part: the rental agreement. I know, I know, it looks like a bunch of legal mumbo jumbo, but trust me, spending a a little time understanding it can save you a whole lot of headache later.

unnormalised: Think of it like this: it's your "janam kundali" for your tenancy. It defines everything – from how much rent you pay (Rs. 15000 maybe?) to what happens if you accidentally break the neighbour's window while playing cricket on the balcony (hypothetically, of course!).
normalised: Think of it like this: it is your "janam kundali" for your tenancy. It defines everything – from how much rent you pay (rupees fifteen thousand maybe?) to what happens if you accidentally break the neighbour's window while playing cricket on the balcony (hypothetically, of course!).

unnormalised: First things first: the term. Usually, rental agreements in Mumbai are for 11 months to avoid stamp duty complications. Pay attention to the start date - maybe it's 01/09/2024 - and the renewal clause. Does it automatically renew? Does the rent increase? By how much? These are crucial questions, especially considering Mumbai's insane rental market.
normalised: First things first: the term. Usually, rental agreements in Mumbai are for eleven months to avoid stamp duty complications. Pay attention to the start date - maybe it is first september two thousand and twenty four - and the renewal clause. Does it automatically renew? Does the rent increase? By how much? These are crucial questions, especially considering Mumbai's insane rental market.

unnormalised: Next, the money matters. Besides the rent, what about the security deposit? Is it two months' rent? Three? And more importantly, when and how do you get it back? Ensure there's a clear clause about deductions for damages. You don't want them deducting for "normal wear and tear," bhai!
normalised: Next, the money matters. Besides the rent, what about the security deposit? Is it two months' rent? Three? And more importantly, when and how do you get it back? Ensure there is a clear clause about deductions for damages. You do not want them deducting for "normal wear and tear," bhai!

unnormalised: Also, understand your responsibilities. Are you responsible for minor repairs like a leaky tap? Or does that fall on the landlord, say, Mr. Patel? What about painting? Are you allowed to hang your favourite Mithun Chakraborty posters? Make sure everything's crystal clear.
normalised: Also, understand your responsibilities. Are you responsible for minor repairs like a leaky tap? Or does that fall on the landlord, say, Mister Patel? What about painting? Are you allowed to hang your favourite Mithun Chakraborty posters? Make sure everything is crystal clear.

unnormalised: Look out for clauses about premature termination. What happens if you need to move out before the 11 months are up? Do you forfeit your deposit? Can you find a replacement tenant? Usually, there’s a notice period of, say, 30 days, sometimes even more.
normalised: Look out for clauses about premature termination. What happens if you need to move out before the eleven months are up? Do you forfeit your deposit? Can you find a replacement tenant? Usually, there is a notice period of, say, thirty days, sometimes even more.

unnormalised: Finally, before you sign on the dotted line, get a lawyer to give it a quick once-over. Even a quick consultation at 10:00 hrs on any given Tuesday can give you peace of mind. And remember, reading the agreement carefully *before* signing is way better than regretting it later. Consider it an investment in your mental peace for the next 11 months, starting on that auspicious date, 15/08/2024! Good luck!
